questions.text: Which technique is used in molecular biology research to study gene expression by detection of RNA in a sample?
questions.solution:
• The northern blot, or RNA blot, is a technique used in molecular biology research to study gene expression by detection of RNA (or isolated mRNA) in a sample.
  • A Southern blot is a method used in molecular biology for detection of a specific DNA sequence in DNA samples. Southern blotting combines transfer of electrophoresis-separated DNA fragments to a filter membrane and subsequent fragment detection by probe hybridization
  • The far-western blot, or far-western blotting, is a molecular biological method based on the technique of western blot to detect protein-protein interaction in vitro. Whereas western blot uses an antibody probe to detect a protein of interest, far-western blot uses a non-antibody probe which can bind the protein of interest. Thus, whereas western blotting is used for the detection of certain proteins, far-western blotting is employed to detect protein/protein interactions.
  • The northwestern blot, also known as the northwestern assay, is a hybrid analytical technique of the western blot and the northern blot, and is used in molecular biology to detect interactions between RNA and proteins.
  • The eastern blot, or eastern blotting, is a biochemical technique used to analyze protein post-translational modifications including the addition of lipids, phosphates, and glycoconjugates. It is most often used to detect carbohydrate epitopes. Thus, eastern blot can be considered an extension of the biochemical technique of western blot.
  • The far-eastern blot, or far-eastern blotting, is a technique for the analysis of lipids separated by high-performance thin layer chromatography (HPTLC).

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Chapter 7, Pg 66-69

questions.text: Antibiotic sensitivity testing is usually done on:
questions.solution:
• Mueller-Hinton agar was co-developed by a microbiologist John Howard Mueller and a veterinary scientist Jane Hinton at Harvard university as a culture for gonococcus and meningococcus.
  • Mueller-Hinton agar is a microbiological growth medium that is commonly used for antibiotic susceptibility testing, specifically disk diffusion tests.
  • It has a few properties that make it excellent for antibiotic use.
    • It is a nonselective, non differential medium. This means that almost all organisms plated on it will grow.
    • It contains starch. Starch is known to absorb toxins released from bacteria, so that they cannot interfere with the antibiotics.
    • It is a loose agar. This allows for better diffusion of the antibiotics than most other plates. A better diffusion leads to a truer zone of inhibition.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Chapter 4, Pg 40-45

choices.text: The structure to be demonstrated is stained
The structure to be demonstrated is not stained
The background and structure are stained

questions.text: True statement about negative staining is:
questions.solution: Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Chapter 2, Pg 12

questions.text: A researcher wishes to study the effect of an antimicrobial that inhibits peptidoglycan synthesis of bacteria. In which phase of the growth curve should he observe the maximum effect of the antimicrobial?
questions.solution:
• Lag phase:
    • Vigorous metabolic activity occurs but cells do not divide
    • Few minutes up to many hours
  • Log (logarithmic/Exponential) phase
    • Rapid cell division occurs
    • Lactam drugs act during this phase when cells are making peptidoglycan 3
  • Stationary phase
    • Nutrient depletion or toxic products
    • growth slows till number of new cells produced = the number of cells that die
  • Death phase
    • Decline in the number of viable bacteria

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Chapter 2, Pg 23-25

choices.text: It needs carrier to induce immune response
It has no association with MHC

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about hapten?
questions.solution:
• Hapten is an incomplete antigen.
  • It is not capable of inducting antibody due to smaller size (molecular weight).
  • It can be made complete by combining it with large sized inert carrier particles to induce antibody production.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Chapter 15, Pg 148-150

questions.text:
A 6 year old child was brought to OPD with complaints of fever, sore throat and difficulty in swallowing. His past history is significant for not taking any vaccines for his age. On a clinical examination, the following picture was seen.

What is the mechanism of toxin released by causative organisms for the same?
questions.solution:
Virulence Factors (Diphtheria Toxin):

Diphtheria toxin (DT) is the primary virulence factor responsible for diphtheria.

  • The toxin is synthesized in the precursor form of molecular weight 58,700 kDa containing a polypeptide made up of 535 amino acids.
  • Toxin has two fragments; A (active) and B (binding) of molecular weight 121,500 and 37,200 kDa respectively.
  • Fragment B is the binding fragment which binds to the host cell receptors (such as epidermal growth factor) and helps in entry of fragment A.
  • Fragment A is the active fragment, gets internalized into the cell and then acts by the mechanism given below.

Mechanism of Diphtheria Toxin (OT)

  • Fragment A is the active fragment, which causes ADP ribosylation of elongation factor 2 (EF-2) -> leads to inhibition of EF-2 -> leads to inhibition of translation - step of protein synthesis.
  • Exotoxin A of pseudomonas has a similar mechanism like that of DT.

Factors Regulating Toxin Production

The production of diphtheria toxin is dependent on various factors.

  • Phage coded: DT is coded by a bacteriophage called beta-corynephage, carrying tox gene. C. diphtheriae remains toxigenic as long as the phages are present inside the bacilli (lysogenic conversion).
  • Iron concentration: the toxin production depends on optimum concentration of iron (0.1 mg per litre). Higher levels of iron inhibit toxin synthesis by upregulating DT repressor genes in the bacterial chromosome.
  • DT repressor gene (DtxR): It is an iron-dependent negative regulator of DT production and iron uptake in C. diphtheriae.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page no: 600

questions.text: Which of the following is the causative organism of the above clinical presentation in the patient visiting Ophthalmology OPD?
questions.solution:
Moraxella lacunata:

It is also called Moraxella Axenfeld bacillus. It is non-fermenting gram-negative rod-shaped and generally present as pairs. It causes catarrhal conjunctivitis and angular conjunctivitis.

Moraxella catarrhalis:

Is a commensal of upper respiratory tract and genital tract.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page no: 780

questions.text:
A 36 year old male patient having multiple sex partners presented to your OPD with genital ulcers that are painful and bleeds on touch. On clinical examination, inguinal lymph nodes are enlarged and tender

What is the most likely diagnosis and its causative organism?
questions.solution:
Haemophilus ducreyi is an etiologic agent of chancroid (or soft chancre), a sexually transmitted infection (STI) characterized by: Painful genital ulceration that bleeds easily; no inflammation of the surrounding skin Enlarged, tender inguinal lymph nodes (bubo). Incubation period can range from 4-7 days. There is no immunity following the infection; however, hypersensitivity may develop.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page no: 762

questions.text: Name species of vibrio which shows 'Kanagawa' phenomena and grows in a halophilic media of upto 8% salt solution. Which of the following vibrio species are you most likely referring to?
questions.solution:
• Parahemolyticus shows kanagawa phenomenon on wagatsuma agar.
  • It grows in upto 8% salt solution, shows swarming growth on blood agar.
  • It is known to cause invasive diarrhea.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, byApurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page 417

questions.text: Vietnam time-bomb disease is caused by?
questions.solution:
B. Pseudomallei is the causative agent of melioidosis.

Long latent period: Manifestations are exacerbated long after the exposure; hence melioidosis is also known as 'Vietnam time-bomb disease'.

  • Bioterrorism: B. pseudomallei can be used as a potential agent of biological warfare.
  • Geographical distribution: Melioidosis is restricted 10 Southeast Asia and northern Australia. In India, melioidosis has been reported from many stares such as Tamil Nadu, Maharashtra, Orissa, West Bengal, Pondicherry and Kerala.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page no: 342

questions.text: Media used for the isolation of Bordetella pertussis is?
questions.solution:
B. pertussis is a strict aerobe, grows best al 35-37°C. lt is a fastidious organism, requires special complex media for primary isolation, such as

  • Charcoal agar supplemented with 10% horse blood and cephalexin (Regan and Lowe medium). It is currently medium of choice.

Bordet-Gengou glycerine-potato-blood agar was a traditional medium used before. (colonies are greyish white, convex with a shiny surface appear after 3- 5 days, described as mercury drops or bisected pearls appearance)

questions.text: Erythema migrans is seen in?
questions.solution:
Lyme disease occurs through four stages:

  • Stage l: Early localized infection: After an incubation period of 3-32 days, an annular maculopapular lesion develops at the site of die tick bite called erythema migrans, commonly involving thigh, groin, and axilla.
  • Stage 2: Early disseminated infection: B. burgdoiferi spread hematogenously, 10 many sites within days or weeks resulting in:
    • Secondary annular skin lesions
    • Musculoskeletal pain (arthralgia) Profound malaise and fatigue Neurological abnormalities, which occur in JS% of cases and include meningitis, encephalitis and a typical lymphocytic meningoradiculitis seen in cases from Europe and Asia; called Banwarth's syndrome.
    • Cardiac involvement occurs in 8% of cases, including atrioventricular block
  • Stage 3: About 60% of untreated patients develop frank arthritis involving large joints (especially the knees), lasting for weeks or months in a given joint Some cases of Lyme arthritis are refractory for treatment. Acrodermatitis chronica atrophicans is a late skin manifestation caused by B.afzelii (affecting elderly women).
  • Post-Lyme syndrome (Chronic): Few patients present with chronic fatigue symptoms and neurocognitive manifestations, develops after months to years of infection.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with ulcerated lesions. Microscopy reveals following structure. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: • Paracoccidioidomycosis (also known as South American blastomycosis, Lutz-Splendore-de Almeida disease) it causes Lutz mycosis.

questions.text: A patient presents to ENT clinic with following presentation. The culture of organism is done. What is the causative agent
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario along with the otoscopic image showing black-headed filamentous growth is suggestive of otomycosis by Aspergillus niger.
  • Irritation and itching are the most predominant symptoms of Aspergillus niger infection. Pain is predominant in Aspergillus flavus infection.
  • The fungal mass in otomycosis is likened to a wet blotting paper/wet newspaper appearance. The appearances of otomycosis on otoscopy and the causative organisms are:
    • Black-headed filamentous growth - Aspergillus niger infection
    • Green or brown - Aspergillus fumigatus infection
    • White and creamy deposit - Candida infection Rhizopus oryzae is one of the causative agents of mucormycosis.
  • The common clinical form of this opportunistic infection is rhino-orbital- cerebral mucormycosis (ROCM). It is rarely implicated in otomycosis.

Reference: Textbook of Ear, Nose, Throat and Head and Neck Surgery: Clinical and Practical; 3rd edition by Hazarika Pg. 52

questions.text: Virus which shows the presence of triple layer capsid and segmented RNA is?
questions.solution:
Rotaviruses are about 60-80 nm in size and possess icosahedral symmetry.

  • Surrounded by a triple layered capsid.
  • Possess segmented dsRNA (11 segments)
  • Proteins: There are six structural viral proteins (VP1 and VP7 except VP5) and six non-structural proteins (NSPI - 6)
  • Viral protein (VP6) is group-specific.
  • VP7 (forms outer capsid layer) andVP4 (forms spikes that emanate through the outer capsid layer) are strong inducers of neutralizing antibodies and are type specific.

questions.text: Identify the worm which has barrel shaped eggs with mucus plugs
questions.solution:
Trichuris trichura is also called as whipworm as the adult worm resembles to a handle of a whip.

Eggs are barrel shaped surrounded by a shell, bear mucus plug at both the poles. Elongated, measures 50–54 µm long and 22–23 µm wide.

Unembryonated when firstly passed. Bile stained. yellowish brown in colour (in saline mount)

Floats in saturated salt solution.

questions.text: What is the infective stage of guinea worm disease?
questions.solution:
Host: There are two types of hosts:

  1. Definitive host: Man
  2. Intermediate host: Copepods (Cyclops)

Infective form: Third stage filariform larvae.

Mode of transmission: Man gets infection by drinking fresh water from stagnant pools containing minute fresh water crustaceans (Cyclops) infected with L3 larvae.

choices.text: Wet mount examination for characteristic jerky motility
Gram stain demonstration of intracellular diplococci
Demonstration of clue cells by gram stain

questions.text: A young adult female having profuse yellowish green offensive vaginal discharge, dysuria and dyspareunia has come to the STI clinic. Upon physical examination, mucosa has an erythematous, punctate and papilliform appearance. (Strawberry mucosa). Which rapid test/technique helps to find out etiological agent.
questions.solution:
Option A – This is a case of Trichomonas vaginalis infection which can be diagnosed by examining saline wet mount of vaginal discharge. As characteristic jerky and twitching motility of trophozoite is rapidly lost outside the body, it should be examined immediately upon collection. Offensive yellowish green profuse discharge along with Strawberry mucosa is characteristic of infection.

Other causes of vaginitis are : fungal Candida species (demonstrated by KOH preparation) in which thick, white, curdy or cheesy discharge is produced. Bacterial by Gardnerella vaginalis (demonstrated by clue cells) has profuse, thin, watery discharge with fishy smell. N.gonorrhoeae typically causes cervicitis and not vaginitis. (Gram stain demonstration of intracellular diplococci).

Reference : Paniker’s textbook of Parasitology - 8th Edition, Pg. No. -37

questions.text: A 45-year man complains of high-grade fever, malaise and body ache for 4 days. He has recently returned from a vacation in Brazil. Laboratory investigation reveals pancytopenia and decreased hemoglobin. A blood smear shows ring shaped trophozoites inside RBCs. Many RBCs have >1 ring. Rapid Antigen Test (RAT) for HRP-II antigen was negative. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Option D - Babesia are intraerythrocytic coccidian parasites that morphologically resemble plasmodia. They are causing malaria-like illness and can lead to severe anemia with hemoglobinuria. They occur as trophozoite form inside RBC.
  • As more than one ring per RBC is present, they morphologically confuse with Plasmodium falciparum. The distinguished features include absence of schizonts & gametocytes and presence of tetrads (four ring) that is maltase cross appearance are pathognomonic of babesia

Reference: Paniker’s textbook of Parasitology - 8th Edition, Pg. No. -87

questions.text: A Korean visitor came to India is admitted to hospital because of chest pain and night sweats. He has had a productive cough since arriving in India, now he has a few episodes of hemoptysis too. The sputum sample is speckled with brown granules, which upon microscopic examination are identified as parasite ova. These same ova are present in the stool (shown in the image). What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Option B - P.westermani is a lung fluke which causes peribronchial granuloma and pneumonitis. The patients usually presented with cough, chest pain and hemoptysis.
  • Viscous septum is speckled with golden brown eggs. Presence of operculated, golden-brown, 100 x 50 μ size eggs are diagnostics.
  • Infection occurs due to consumption of raw or undercooked crab or crayfish which is practiced in parts of Southeast Asia like Korea, Taiwan, China & Japan.

Reference: Paniker’s textbook of Parasitology - 8th Edition, Pg. No. -161

choices.text: Attachment of the virus with the co-receptor CXCR4 molecule present on T-lymphocytes.
Spike protein(S) binds to angiotensin converting enzyme 2(ACE 2 receptor) on the human cell.
Viral entry into host cells is mediated by binding to CD155 receptors
Binding to host cell intracellular adhesion molecule-1(ICAM-1)

questions.text: A 50 year old business man was admitted to the ICU with the complaints of fever , shortness of breath, and loss of smell since 3 days. After 24 hours he was tachypneic (30/min) with decreased O2 saturation (SPO2-75%) and required emergency intubation. Chest X-ray showed bilateral consolidation and HR-CT showed ground glass appearance. Lab investigations revealed elevated PCT, D-dimer, and ferritin levels. The mechanism of viral entry is by
questions.solution:
Spike protein(S) binds to angiotensin converting enzyme 2(ACE 2 receptor) on the human cell.

The coronavirus genome is comprised of ∼30000 nucleotides. It encodes four structural proteins, Nucleocapsid (N) protein, Membrane (M) protein, Spike (S) protein and Envelop (E) protein and several non-structural proteins (nsp). The mechanism of viral entry and replication and RNA packing in the human cell is mapped in Figure 1. The coronavirus spike (S) protein attaches to angiotensin converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) receptors that is found on the surface of many human cells, including those in the lungs allowing virus entry.

FIGURE-1

Reference: Novel 2019 coronavirus structure, mechanism of action, antiviral drug promises and rule out against its treatment

Subramanian Boopathi, Adolfo B. Poma, and Ponmalai Kolandaivel

questions.text: A 55 year old cave explorer visits the physician OPD with the complaints of chills, non productive cough, and skin lesions since 5 days. He gives a history of travel to a bird sanctuary in South America 15 days back. Chest X-ray reveals patchy infiltrate with hilar lymphadenopathy. Histopathological examination of lymphnodes revealed tiny oval yeast cells within macrophages. Fungal culture after week showed mycelial growth. LPCB mount revealed tuberculate conidia with thick walls and finger like projections. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis.
questions.solution:
• Caused by dimorphic fungi Histoplasma capsulatum.
  • Occurs worldwide but endemic in USA.

Lab diagnosis:- histopathological examination reveals tiny oval yeast cells with narrow based budding present inside the macrophages.

Culture :- Gold standard diagnostic method

  • As it is a dimorphic fungus,it is seen in two forms
  • At 37*c it is seen as yeast form i.e creamy white colonies.
  • At 25*c it is seen as white to buff brown colonies and has two conidia (1) Tuberculate macroconidia with finger like projections, (2) Microconidia are small and smooth walled.

Others :-

Option A - Paracoccidioidomycosis :- culture on SDA

  • At 25*c - mycelium form.
  • At 37*c - yeast form appearance , resembles mickey mouse or pilot wheel.

Option B - Coccidioidomycosis :- culture on SDA

  • Grows as a mould at both 25*c and 37*c.
  • Forms spherules at 37*c.

Option C :- Blastomycosis - growth on SDA

  • At 25*c - mycelium with small pear shaped conidia.
  • At 37*c - mould to yeast conversion occurs.

Option E :- Aspergillosis - caused by mould called aspergillus.

  • LPCB mount - conidia is seen arising from cells called sterigmata.
  • Conidia arise from vesicles either from upper half or the entire surface.

Reference: Koneman's color atlas and textbook of diagnostic microbiology 6th edition Page-2614.

questions.text: A group of students attended a midnight buffet dinner on New year's eve with a lavish spread on chicken sandwiches, salads and pastries. Early next morning they complained of nausea and 7-8 episodes of vomiting. Which of the following can be the causative organism?
questions.solution:
It is caused by entertoxin of staphylococcus aureus. It is a preformed toxin, hence the incubation period is short of about 1-6 hrs. symptoms are characterised by vomiting , nausea, hypotension and dehydration. The most important source of infection is a carrier of staphylococcus aureus usually a food handler. Most common food items involved are bakery food, custards, milk products, and processed meats.

Other options:-

  1. Bacillus cereus- the common food sources are vegetables, cereals, meats. It is also seen after consumption of Chinese fried rice. Incubation period can be between 1-16 hrs.
  2. Shigella- is associated with desentry. It is characterised by diarrhea associated with blood and mucus. Incubation period is > 16 hrs.
  3. Vibrio cholera- is associated with consumption of shell fish and contaminated water. Symptoms of watery diarrhea is seen. The incubation period is usually > 16 hrs. It can be identified by darting motility of vibrio in hanging drop preparation.
  4. Enterohaemorrhagic E.coli- the common food sources are apple juice, raw vegetables, salami, ground beef. It is associated bloody diarrhea.
  5. Answer

Reference: Mandell,Douglas and Benett's principles and practice of infectious diseases 8th edition Page-2237.

Koneman's color atlas and textbook of diagnostic microbiology 6th edition Page-1321.

choices.text: Separation of epidermal layer with denuded underlying skin

questions.text: A 5 yr old was brought to the paediatric OPD with the complaints of 3-4 skin lesions on the face. On examination the lesions were painless, vesicular which on rupturing showed yellowish-brown exudates. There is no history of pain. Nikolsky's sign - negative. There are signs of autoinoculation with many lesions. Gram staining from the exudates revealed gram positive cocci in chains. Culture showed the presence of Beta haemolytic pin point colonies. What is the most characteristic feature of this clinical case be?
questions.solution:
1. E) Honeycomb like crusted lesions - impetigo is a superficial infection of skin caused primarily by group A streptococcus and rarely by other streptococci and staphylococcus aureus. Most common site involves the face and legs. Lesions are painful and there is no history of fever. Individual lesions are seen as red papules which then form pustular lesion which breakdown and coalesce to form honey comb like crust.

Other options:-

  1. Red, Peau'd orange appearance is seen in cellulitis which involves the skin and superficial lymphatics. Most common sites are lower extremities and malar area. Such appearance is seen in erysipelas caused by Strepococcus pyogenes.
  2. Pastia lines are rash seen in skin folds in scarlet fever. Scarlet fever is mediated by streptococcal toxins SPE-A,B,C.
  3. Separation of epidermal layer with denuded underlying skin, this occurs in staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome. Separation of outer epidermal layer leaving denuded underlined skin is called Nikolsky's sign.
  4. Sandpaper feel-rash is seen scarlet fever. This occurs either due to circulating toxin or as a result of hypersensitivity reaction.
  5. Answer

Reference: Koneman's color atlas and textbook of diagnostic microbiology 6th edition Page-1434.

Mandell,Douglas and Benett principles and practice of infectious diseases 8th edition Page-2293.

Essentials of medical microbiology Apurba Sankar Sastry, Sandhya Bhat K Page-224.

choices.text: Cocci arranged in pairs and at right angle to each other
Gram positive cocci arranged in chains
Gram negative half moon shaped diplococci

questions.text:
A 45 yr old male was rushed to the ER with complaints of fever, chills, shortness of breath and decreased urine output since last 6 days. There is a past H/O cystoscopy performed for stricture urethra. Investigation revealed the following:-
1. Complete urine examination - showed plenty of pus cells/HPF
2. Urine culture on Mac Conkey agar medium - tiny pink colonies, growth in presence of 6.5% NACL and 40% Bile.
3. Antibiotic sensitivity showed resistance to pencillin, aminoglycosides, vancomycin,.
What is the finding seen in gram staining?
questions.solution:
A) Cocci arranged in pairs and at right angle to each other - enterococci are gram positive oval cocci arranged in pairs. Cocci are arranged at right angle to each other

( spectacle-eyed appearance ). They grow in extreme conditions such as 45*C and 10*C, 6.5% NACL, pH 9.6, 40% bile.

Other options:-

  1. Answer
  2. Gram positive cocci arranged in chains Streptococci are arranged in chains due to single plain of division.
  3. Gram negative kidney shaped diplococcic - gonococcus is seen as gram negative kidney shaped diplococcic.
  4. Gram negative half moon shaped diplococcic - meningococci is seen as gram negative half moon shaped/lens shaped diplococci which is present inside polymorphs.
  5. Gram positive cocci in tetrads - micrococcus are usually arranged in tetrads. They are skin commensals under obligate aerobes.

Reference:Koneman's color atlas and textbook of diagnostic microbiology 6th edition Page-1526.

questions.text: A 26 yr old woman visits a gynaecology out patient department with abdominal pain, vaginal discharge since 1 week. There is a history of unprotected sexual contact 2 weeks back. A high cervical swab was taken and transported in a charcoal containing medium to the lab. Gram staining revealed gram negative intracellular diplococci. Which organism is likely to cause this sexually transmitted disease?
questions.solution:
D) Neisseria gonorrhoea - gonococcal infection usually presents as mucopurulent cervisitis. Mode of transmission is by sexual contact or from mother to baby during birth. Cervical swab is the preferred specimen. It is transported in Stuart's and Amies transport medium. Gram staining reveals gram negative intracellular kidney shaped diplococci.

Other options:-

  1. Haemophillus ducreyi - causes sexually transmitted disease known as chancroid. It presents with genital ulcers and enlarged inguinal lymphnodes( bubo ). Microscopy shows gram negative coccobacilli. The arrangement is known as rail track appearance or school of fish appearance.
  2. Chlamydia trachomatis - is most important cause of non-gonococcal urethritis, epididymitis, proctitis, post gonococcal urethritis. The patient presents with mucopurulent discharge, dysuria. Microscopy with Lugol's iodine detects inclusion bodies of Chlamydia.
  3. Treponoma pallidium - is the causative agent of the sexually transmitted disease syphillis. Clinical manifestations of syphillis can be divided into 4 stages - 1) primary, 2) secondary, 3) latent, 4) tertiary. Primary syphillis is characterised by a painless ulcer which is hard and indurated. Most common sites are - penis, cervix or labia, anal canal, rectum.
  4. Answer
  5. Gardenerella vaginalis - causes a condition known as bacterial vaginosis. Bacterial vaginosis is clinically diagnosed Amsel's criteria:-
  6. profuse thin vaginal discharge.
  7. pH of vaginal discharge more than 4.5.
  8. fishy odour immediately after vaginal secretion is mixed with 10% KOH.
  9. Clue cells.

Reference: Koneman's color atlas and textbook of diagnostic microbiology 6th edition Page-1200.

Mandell,Douglas and Benett's principles and practice of infectious diseases 8th edition Page-2446.

questions.text:
A 55 yr old K/C/O diabetes mellitus comes to the OPD with complaints of burning micturation, increased urgency and feeling of incomplete bladder emptying.
- Urinalysis showed pyuria.
- USG abdomen and pelvis revealed pyelonephritis along with bladder thickening.
- PSA (prostate specific antigen) is negative
- Urine culture reveals E.coli < 10^5 CFU/ ml.
Which of the following virulence factor is the most important in patient's condition?
questions.solution:
These fimbriae haemagglutinate with RBC's and cannot be inhibited by mannose.They help in colonisation of uroepithelial cells, and are expressed by uropathogenic Ecoli.

Other options:-

A)Fraction 1 antigen-it is an important virulence factor of yersinia pestis.it mainly acts by inhibiting macrophage phagocytosis.

B)Edema factor- It is an important virulence factor of Bacillus anthracis.It acts as adenyl cyclase and increases host cell cAMP.It is responsible for edema seen in anthrax.

C)Fibrinolysin-It is also known as streptokinase.It is an important virulence factor of streptococcus pyogenes.It activates plasminogen to plasmin ,which causes breakdown of fibrin barrier around the affected site and helps in the spread of the infection

E)Cable pilus-It is an important virulence factor of Burkholderia cepacia.these filamentous structures have the ability to bind to respiratory epithelium and mucin.The role of burkholderia cepacia is of great significance in cystic fibrosis.

questions.text: A 35 yr old hiker visits a rheumatology clinic with C/O joint pains since 20 days mainly involving the large joints. There is a H/O presence of annular maculopapular lesions on the thigh and feet since 10 days. Travel H/O to Rhode island a month back on a hiking trip was given. What is the probable source of infection in the case?
questions.solution:
D) Lyme disease - is caused by borrelia burgdorferi. Rodents and deers are the main reservoirs of lyme disease. It is widespread in USA. Lyme disease is transmitted by tick bite( ixodes ricinus complex ). Clinical manifestations are divided into 4 stages:-

  • Stage 1 - annular maculopapular lesion called erythema migrans( annular bulls-eye pattern rash ) is seen on the thigh, groin and axilla.
  • Stage 2 - secondary annular lesions and musculoskeletal pain is seen.
  • Stage 3 - patients develop frank arthritis involving large joints especially knees.
  • Stage 4 - post lyme syndrome.

Other options:-

A) Rheumatoid arthritis - it is a chronic inflammatory disease that effects more than one joint. It is associated with pain, swelling and deformity as the tissue that lines the joint become inflamed and thickened.

B) Epidemic typhus - is caused by rickettsia prowuazekii. Human body louse is the vector for epidemic typhus. Epidemic typhus manifests as a rash on the upper trunk usually on 5th day and severe myalgia.

C) Chikungunya - transmission of chikungunya primarily occurs by bites of aedes aegypti mosquito during day time. Most common symptoms are fever with joint pain. Arthritis is usually edematous migratory and effects small joints of wrists and ankles.

E) Dengue fever - dengue virus is arbovirus and has 4 serotypes DEN 1 to DEN 4. Aedes aegypti is a principle vector followed by aedes albopictus. Symptoms seen are abrupt onset of high fever, maculopapular rash on the chest and upper limbs.

Reference: Mandell,Douglas and Benett's principles and practice of infectious diseases 8th edition Page-2725.

choices.text: Ingestion of water contaminated with stool of dogs

questions.text: A 45 yr old K/C/O HIV presents to a family physician with multiple reddish purple hemangioma like lesions, 3mm in size since 3 months. There is a H/O fever, chills, weight loss since 1 month. On examination and enlarged axillary lymph nodes was felt. Warthin - Starry silver nitrate staining of lymph nodes smear detected clumps of bacteria. What is the probable animal source of the organism responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Bacillary angiomatosis is an angio-proliferative disorder involving skin and other organs. It is associated with HIV and other immuno-compromised conditions. Transmission occurs by scratch or bite of a cat. Cat fleas are associated with cat to cat transmission but not cat to human transmission. It is caused by Bartonella henselae and Bartonella Quintana.

Other options:-

A) Answer

B) Rat urine - leptospirosis is zoonotic disease. Transmission occurs by indirect contact with water, soil, or wet surfaces contaminated with animal urine( rats, dogs, cattle, pigs ) It can also be transmitted by urine and products of parturition, placenta of infected animals.

C) Ingestion of water contaminated with stool of dogs - hydatid disease is caused by the larval infection of tapeworm Echinococcus granulosus. The definitive host of the cystode carnivore such as dogs. Humans and other host ingest eggs or gravid proglottids which are excreted by the definitive host faeces causing the infections.

D) Tick bite - Lyme disease is caused by Borrelia burgdorferi and is transmitted by tick bite. The tick must atleast attach for 24 hrs for transmission of Borrelia burgdorferi.

E) Consumption of measly cooked pork - Taenia solium is a tapeworm which is acquired by eating raw or undercooked measly pork. The pork meat has cysticerci which is the larval stage that matures into adult tapeworm in human intestine

Reference: Mandell,Douglas and Benett's principles and practice of infectious diseases 8th edition Page-2652

questions.text: Identify the phenomenon exhibited by H.influenzae in blood agar
questions.solution:
Most strains of Haemophilus spp do not grow on 5% sheep blood agar, which contains hemin (factor X) but lacks NAD (factor V).

Haemophilus influenzae uses factor X to produce essential respiratory enzymes like cytochromes, catalases and peroxidases. Factor V is used as an electron carrier in the body's oxidation-reduction system.

Staphylococcus aureus produces NAD as a metabolic by-product when growing in culture medium containing blood. Therefore, Haemophilus spp can grow on sheep blood agar very close to colonies of Staphylococcus aureus (because it produces the NAD factor), this phenomenon is known as satellitism.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms produces red pigment called prodigiosin?
questions.solution:
S marcescens produces characteristic red non diffusible pigment called prodigiosin.

It is a saprophyte found in water, soil and food.

It may grow in sputum after collection and makes the sputum red (due to pigment production) This condition is known as pseudohemoptysis.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page

questions.text: Which of the following is Scotochromogen?
questions.solution:
Scotochromogens produce pigment even in the dark.

M.scrofulaceum-causes scrofula (cervical lymphadenitis) in children.

M.gordonae is a commensal in tap water

M.kansasii-causes chronic pulmonary disease resembling tuberculosis.

questions.text: The type of colonies seen in the above picture is a finding associated with which organism?
questions.solution:
Autolysin is responsible for draughtsman or carom coin appearance of pneumococcal colonies.

Streptococcus pneumoniae also contains within itself the enzymatic ability to disrupt and to disintegrate the cells (bacterial peptidoglycan).

questions.text: Selective media for vibrio
questions.solution:
TCBS(thiosulfate citrate bile salts sucrose agar is selective media for Vibrio.

V.cholerae produces yellow colonies as it ferments sucrose.

V.parahemolyticus produces green colonies.

questions.text: Cryoglobulins seen in which of the following hepatitis virus infection?
questions.solution:
Cryoglobulinemia is an extrahepatic manifestation seen in hepatitis C INFECTION

Extrahepatic manifestations are seen due to deposition of circulating immune complexes in extra hepatic sites.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page 1/e 537,2/ep 560-561

questions.text: A newborn presents with chorioretinitis, hypoplasia of limbs and scaring of hands. Most probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Hypoplasia of limbs and scarring of hands-S/O-Fetal varicella syndrome

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page 1/e 438,2/ep 454-455

choices.text: Acute Hepatitis B patient with high infectivity

questions.text:
A hospital worker is found to be HBsAg (+)ve. Further serum investigations showed HBe(+)ve and IgG anti HBc(+)ve
The health worker is
questions.solution: Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 2nd edition, page 557

questions.text: The most common organism causing diarrhea in adults associated with shell fish ingestion
questions.solution:
Noroviruses causes gastroenteritis in all age groups.

Norovirus accounts for majority of adult outbreaks of gastroenteritis.

Shellfish and salad ingredients are the foods often implicated in norovirus outbreaks.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 2nd edition, page 547-548

questions.text: A clinical specimen was obtained from the wound of a patient diagnosed as nocardiosis. For the selective isolation of nocardia species, which one of the following would be the best method
questions.solution:
Nocardia are among the few aerobic micro-organisms that paraffin as a sole source of carbon.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 2nd edition, page 306-307 Harrison 19/e p1084-87,20/e p1218

questions.text: An anaerobe causing multiple abscess with discharging sinus, demonstrating sulphur granules in pus are used to diagnose
questions.solution:
Actinomycosis is an anaerobic infection present as a painless,slow growing,hard mass with cutaneous fistulas, with discharging granules.

Actinomyces are branching Gram positive filamentous bacilli.

Sulphur granules in pus or tissue is a characteristic feature of actinomycosis infection.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 2nd edition, page 304-305

questions.text: Which of the following is not useful for the prevention of KFD?
questions.solution:
Control measures of KFD:-

A)Vector control

b)Killed KFD vaccine

c)Personal protection by using mosquito repellents.

Since heavy tick population in forest is attributed to free roaming of cattle, the restriction of cattle movement is thought to cause reduction of vector population.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 2nd edition, page 514,park 24/e p305/306

questions.text: A diabetic patient suffers from soft tissue infection and microbiological examination reveal the infection being caused by fungi with aseptate and broad hyphae. Which of the following fungus is responsible for this infection?
questions.solution:
Broad aseptate hyphae-belong to family zygomycetes

Eg;-Rhizopus, Mucor, Absidia, Apophysomyces

Narrow septate hyphae-Eg-Aspergillus, Pencillium, Fusarium

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 2nd edition, page 594

questions.text: All of the following methods are used for the diagnosis of HIV infection in a 2 month old child except
questions.solution:
Anti-HIV antibody detection by ELISA or any other method is done only after 18 months of birth when all the maternal antibodies would disappear.

HIV diagnosis<18 months

a)HIV DNA detection (BEST)

B)p24 antigen

C)HIV RNA detection

D)Virus isolation

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 2nd edition, page 531-532

questions.text: A women presented to a dermatology OPD with dome-shaped warty lesions with a dimpled centre since 2 months, similar lesions was also noticed in her daughter (seen in the image) causative agent is?
questions.solution:
Molluscum contagiosum lesions are flesh-coloured, dome shaped and pearly in appearance.

They are often 1-5 mm in diameter with dimpled centre.

It is extremely contagious and is transmitted by direct or indirect contact.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 2nd edition, page 471

questions.text: The image shown below is associated with which of the following virus?
questions.solution:
Hairy leukoplakia is a wart-like growth of epithelial cells of the tongue developed in HIV-infected patients and transplant recipients.

Acyclovir is useful in the treatment of oral hairy leukoplakia.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 2nd edition, page 460

questions.text: The most common manifestation of mumps is?
questions.solution:
The most common manifestation is parotitis, and the common complication is orchitis.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 2nd edition, page 484

questions.text: Mechanism of action of tetanospasmin
questions.solution:
MOA-Acts presynaptically and inhibits glycine and GABA release that leads to spastic contraction of muscles.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 2nd edition, page 271

questions.text: Frie test is used for
questions.solution:
Frie's test is an intradermal test using crude chlamydial antigen from bubo pus used for detection of LGV.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 2nd edition, page 417

questions.text: A patient has history of sexual intercourse with a commercial sex worker 3 days back,has developed genital discharge resembling "flow of seeds" What medium should be used for culture of discharge material?
questions.solution:
Genital discharge resembling "flow of seed" is suggestive of gonococcal urethritis.

Selective media for culture of gonococcus-Thayer-Martin medium.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 2nd edition, page 250

questions.text: A 40 year old sexually active male is having urethral discharge since 8 months along with burning micturition. Gram staining smear of urethral swab shows the following picture. The causative organism is
questions.solution:
Picture shows gram negative cocci in pairs, kidney shaped suggestive of Gonococcus.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 2nd edition, page 250.
